summary.seg: This fragment consists of four folios of a Gospel book, containing part of the Gospel of Matthew. The characteristics of the script suggest that it was produced in Cyprus or the Levant, probably in the late 12th or 13th century.

msItem.title: Gospel of Matthew
msItem.note: Gregory-Aland 674; Von Soden ε 271; Scrivener Evan. 620
msItem.filiation: This fragment was categorised by Aland as conforming to the majority text.
msItem.note: The fragment begins during Mt 10:42 and ends during Mt 12:43)
msItem.incipit: f. 1r ψυχροῦν· μόνον εἰς ὄνομα θητοῦ, ἀμὴν λέγω ὑμῖν
msItem.explicit: f. 4v ὅταν δὲ τὸ ἀκάθαρτον πνεύμα· ἐξέλθη ἀπὸ τοῦ ἀνθρώπου

support.material: Parchment (FHHF), of medium thickness and quality.

supportDesc.foliation: The quire is foliated with the numbers 1-4, in Arabic numerals, in pencil, recto, upper right.

collation.p: The fragment consists of 2 bifolia, probably the inner half of a quaternion.

list.item: Quire 18-4 ff. 1-4 The first, second, seventh and eighth folios have probably been lost, with loss of text.

supportDesc.condition: There are areas of dirt and mild water staining.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column of 26 lines. 153 110
Pricking survives in all three margins, but some has been lost to cropping. Ruled in hardpoint, system Leroy 1, type Leroy 32C1.

handNote.p: The text was copied in an upright low epsilon style mixed minuscule script in black ink. There is moderate variation in letter size, and slight flourishing of tails into the margin. There are deletions by expunctuation, but these may be by a later hand.

Syllabic abbreviations and superscript word endings appear only at the end of lines. Breathings are round, and mute iota is absent. There is decorative use of the double dot. There is accentuation of all lengths of nomina sacra. The double grave accent is in use.
The flat-bottomed omega and small x-shaped kappa are present. Distinctive letter-forms include minuscule kappa with very short acenders. There are frequent low epsilon ligatures.
Punctuation used includes the middle and upper points, lower and middle commas and question mark. The end of sections is sometimes marked by an additional point in red ink.
Headings are written in the same style, with greater use of majuscule forms, in red ink.

decoDesc.decoNote: Sections of text begin with minor initials in red ink, at the beginning of the following line where the section begins in mid-line.

additions.p: As part of the original process of production, the scribe has marked the numbers of κεφάλαια (chapters) and Ammonian sections in the margins, and the numbers and headings (τίτλοι) of κεφάλαια in the upper margin, in dark red ink.

A later hand has added marginal lection notes, ἀρχή and τέλος marks indicating the beginning and end of lections in the margins or inserted into the text, and marginal numbers giving a sequential count of lections (ἀναγνώσεις), in bright red ink. There are occasional corrections and notes in Greek by another later hand.
The fragment is marked with the present classmark and the previous classmark T.5, and a modern chapter and verse reference for the beginning of the surviving text, on f. 1r.

binding.p: The fragment has a modern card binding reinforced with cloth inside the spine.

history.origin: The style of script suggests that the manuscript was copied in the late 12th or 13th century. The use of black ink and the low epsilon style script suggest that it was produced in Cyprus or the Levant.
history.provenance: Owned by the Biblical scholar Constantin von Tischendorf (1815-1874) Tischendorf, Constantin von, 1815-1874 .
history.acquisition: Bought by the University Library from Tischendorf's executors in 1876.

availability.p: Entry to read in the Library is permitted only on presentation of a valid reader's card. For information on eligibility and admissions procedures, see Joining the Library). For further information on the availability of the manuscript, please contact the Manuscripts Reading Room.

monogr.title: Novum Testamentum Graece: ad antiquissimos testes denuo recensuit apparatum criticum apposuit Constantinus Tischendorf

monogr.title: Plain Introduction to the Criticism of the New Testament

change.persName: Description and introduction: Christopher Wright. Diplomatic transcription: Filip Sylwestrowicz
